docs.snippet: One of the most memorable moments in the 1992 presidential campaign came on an MTV show when a young woman cheekily asked Bill Clinton: Boxers or briefs?     It took until the last day of the 2008 campaign for the subject of undergarments to come ...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most memorable moments in the 1992 presidential campaign came on an MTV show when a young woman cheekily asked Bill Clinton: Boxers or briefs? It took until the last day of the 2008 campaign for the subject of undergarments to come up again, and it was an MTV interviewer who brought it up.
docs.abstract: Sen Barack Obama implies that he does not favor sagging pants style inspired by some hip-hop artists (M)

docs.snippet: Before Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, there was Gov. Tim Pettigrew of New York, the first black presidential nominee for the Democratic Party. But that happened in 1976, and in the pages of ''Treasure Chest,'' a comic book distributed to Cathol...
docs.lead_paragraph: Before Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, there was Gov. Tim Pettigrew of New York, the first black presidential nominee for the Democratic Party. But that happened in 1976, and in the pages of ''Treasure Chest,'' a comic book distributed to Catholic school students around the country. ''It's been on the edge of reality,'' Berry Reece, author of the series, said of the current election.
docs.abstract: Sen Barack Obama's presidential campaign evokes 1964 comic book series Treasure Chest, which depicted first black presidential nominee; photo (M)

docs.snippet: The day of days was nearly upon voters, and Senators John McCain and Barack Obama each sounded hopeful (but not too confident) and energized (though exhaustion lay behind the smiles) while hopscotching among swing states on Monday.     After 22 mo...
docs.lead_paragraph: The day of days was nearly upon voters, and Senators John McCain and Barack Obama each sounded hopeful (but not too confident) and energized (though exhaustion lay behind the smiles) while hopscotching among swing states on Monday. After 22 months of memorable campaigning there were a few final memorable lines. Mr. Obama, on MTV, criticizing sagging pants: ''Brothers should pull up their pants.'' And Gov. Sarah Palin warning voters in Missouri that Democrats would cut defense spending: ''Do they think terrorists have all of a sudden became the good guys?''
docs.abstract: Presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama each sound hopeful and energized as they hopscotch among swing states in final day of campaigning before election (M)
